text: this is Heather Timmons
reporting from mid whare Colin lucha
pradesh for the new york times it's
early morning in a small village in
India's most populous state a ritual is
being performed a father mourns for his
daughter a 23 year old woman who has
become a symbol of all that is wrong
with the way that India treats women his
name is Bhadra Singh his daughter was
killed after a vicious gang rape in New
Delhi his son is inconsolable the father
is angry I keep thinking the six
culprits should be hanged that's a
possibility idea there he is not the
only one much of India and in fact many
people around the world have been
enraged by the incident
[Applause]
where many families in India scrimp on
their daughter's education mr. Singh did
not school she used to be the first in a
class she loved medicine and she
enrolled in private physiotherapy school
[Music]
sometimes she used to wear a doctor's
coat and show it to me and her mother
and ask how do I look he sold land
borrowed money and worked double shifts
to pay for her education mr. Singh and
all of India have been trying to make
sense of what happened if there was not
such division between rural and urban
cultures then this would not have
happened until today I've never seen or
heard about such incidents I've never
even heard about theft
we've lost our morality which is why
these things happen if we had morals
incidents like this would not happen
still he said that he has not lost hope
[Music]
the outcome from this should be that in
the future next generation our children
should feel safe I think that there will
be change many in India are also hoping
that change will come
